smell_analysis.justification: All diagrams in the provided PDF contain visible elements and are not empty.

All use cases (visual oval elements) are either directly associated with an actor or connected via an 'include' relationship to a use case that is associated with an actor (e.g., 'Vaata kõiki ootel...' on Page 3).
No use cases with identical names associated with the same actor were found in the diagrams.
No distinct model elements with the exact same name were found defined within the same package scope.
No obvious data redundancy (denormalization without Foreign Keys) was detected. Repeated columns like 'reg_aeg' represent distinct timestamps for different entities (Person vs Car).
Use case naming is consistent; all use cases start with an active verb in the imperative mood (e.g., 'Vaata', 'Tuvasta', 'Registreeri').
In the state diagram (Page 9), all states (Ootel, Aktiivne, Mitteaktiivne, etc.) are reachable via transitions from the start node or other reachable states.
In the activity diagram (Page 4), all actions are reachable through the decision branches.

On Page 12, the association between the 'Auto' class and the 'Auto_kategooria_omamine' class is missing a multiplicity indicator on the 'Auto_kategooria_omamine' end (only '0..*' is shown on the Auto end).
No single diagram contains 10 or more central elements (classes, tables, use cases, or states). The most populated diagrams (e.g., Page 15) contain fewer than 10 distinct central table elements.

No single element has 6 or more visual connection lines on a single diagram page. For example, 'Autod' has multiple relationships, but they are distributed across Pages 17 and 18, never exceeding 5 lines on one canvas.
The layout of the diagrams is balanced, with no related elements placed at excessively large distances compared to the average.
All use cases and activity diagram actions start with active verbs (e.g., 'Vaata', 'Otsi', 'Vali').
No class, table, attribute, or use case names were found to be 3 characters or less (excluding allowed abbreviations like 'id' within stereotypes).
Class names are consistently capitalized and singular (e.g., 'Isik', 'Auto', 'Klient').
Attribute and column names start with lowercase letters (e.g., 'nimetus', 'eesnimi').
On Pages 17 and 18, the database table is named 'Autod' (plural for 'Cars'), whereas it should be singular (e.g., 'Auto') to be consistent with N3.3.

No type prefixes (like 'tbl_', 'str') were found. Prefixes used are 'PK_', 'FK_', 'IXFK_', and 'AK_' (Alternate Key), which fall under standard database key notation allowed or similar to the allowed exceptions.
